series.title: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
series.author: Brooks Jensen

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW1002 - The Decisive Metaphor
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
Ever since Henri Cartier-Bresson introduced "the decisive moment" into the photographic lexicon, we've heard it proclaimed as the photographic strategy. Perhaps it is, but I've found that thinking in terms of "the decisive metaphor" has been an even better criteria for directing my work.

episodes.title: LW1001 - The Stephen King Method
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:

episodes.title: LW0998 - Non-negotiables
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0997 - Photography Is Not Mechanical Painting
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
In the pantheon of art media, photography occupies a unique position that allows us to tell a story, but with sufficient time for reflection and developing a deeper understanding. It is so unfortunate that photography, when presented like a painting - in a frame on the wall - tends to promote viewing with a glance. This viewing habit leaves photography's greatest strength untapped.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0996 - Digital Picture Frames
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
.I finally had a chance to look at a new 4K digital picture frame. Fantastic - and, my goodness, where is this leading us? Is it time to consider how this game changer might be changing photography? If not today, should we at least start thinking about what digital frames might imply in the future as the technology continues to evolve?

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0995 - The Burden of Equipment
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
My ideal camera would be perfectly transparent to my creative process, weigh exactly 0.0 pounds, and use one f/1.2 lens that ranged from 14mm to 400mm and be the size of a tennis ball. One can dream, can't one? In the meantime, the struggle with equipment continues.

episodes.title: LW0994 - YouTube, Yikes
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
I've recently immersed myself in YouTube as I needed to learn some tech stuff. As useful as this was, I found YouTube to be just a bit scary in its pressure toward conformity.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0993 - The Golden Hour
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
Is it really necessary to rise at 0:Dark:30 in order to be photographing the landscape during that first light of sun? Is the Golden Hour really magical?

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0992 - The Wonder of Life
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
Here is a great quote from author Dorothy Canfield: "The artist's work is the fatiguing attempt to transform the wonder of life into art."

Publisher/author/podcaster/photographer, Brooks Jensen, is now offering Feedback reviews! Here is your opportunity to have your work affordably reviewed by one of photography's most experienced and sought-after reviewers. These short 10-20 minute commentaries offer an "editor's look" at your photographs or project using screen capture video with audio commentary. Ideas about editing, sequencing, project development, style and presentation, technical suggestions, and more. What feedback are you looking for? Brooks targets his reviews to your specific needs. For more information, visit www.lenswork.com.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0991 - Defining Success
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
How many images are required to be successful in a given situation? If one good image makes a session a success, does it matter at all how many exposures it takes to get there? Curious implications for handheld, slow shutter, image stabilized photography.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0990 - Not Standing Still
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
Beethoven keeps nagging at me. He said, "Art demands of us that we shall not stand still." So, it's his fault that I'm buying a new portrait lens.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0989 - Stop Thinking About Photography
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
Means to an end . . . Means to an end . . . Means to an end. Photography is not the goal; it is the tool we use to reach the goal - some form of artistic expression that uses photography, but not about photography.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0988 - The Shot
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
In my mind, there is something completely different between using a camera to get "the shot" and using a camera to make artwork.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0987 - Shooting Mindset
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary:
In Japan in 2009, I had decided to take only my monopod and work fast and light. I loved the idea, but observed on the first day how I quickly fell into a shoot-move-shoot-move-shoot-move frenetic pattern that degraded into an unconscious and unproductive race for more images.

episodes.seriesTitle: LensWork - Photography and the Creative Process
episodes.title: LW0986 - ISO, Noise, and the Artwork
episodes.author: editor@lenswork.com
episodes.summary: From time to time, I get stuck - unable to leap over a creative block. What do I want to photograph next? That's when my bagful of excuses comes in handy. But truth be told, they are no more than a cover for something more fundamental that needs to be addressed.
